intro: Eschscholzia gigas, commonly known as the giant poppy, is a striking member of the Papaveraceae family native to the western United States. This plant is characterized by its large, showy flowers that can reach up to 12 inches in diameter, typically displaying shades of red, orange, and yellow. Its leaves are palmately lobed and covered in a fine, fuzzy texture, while its stems are thick and woody. Eschscholzia gigas thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often growing in dry, rocky habitats. Due to its rarity and beauty, it is a subject of both botanical interest and conservation efforts.
